title: 103_s1049
content:
The Act titled "Lechuguilla Cave Protection Act of 1993" recognizes the scientific and environmental significance of Lechuguilla Cave and other caves in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. It aims to protect these caves from adverse effects of mineral exploration and development. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS

Cave protection area - lands within the area depicted on the map in section 4(b).
Secretary - Secretary of the Interior.
Other terms - terms have the same meaning as in the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976.

SEC. 4. LAND WITHDRAWAL. The approximately 6,280 acres of public lands within the cave protection area are withdrawn from all forms of appropriation or disposal under public land laws. The lands are described in a map filed in April 1993. The Secretary will publish a notice with the legal description in the Federal Register. The Secretary will publish a notice in the Federal Register with the legal description of the lands withdrawn under the cave protection area, as required by the Act. The detailed map and legal description filed in April 1993 will have the same force and effect as if included in the Act, with the Secretary allowed to correct any errors. The public lands withdrawn under subsection (a) shall be managed by the Secretary through the Bureau of Land Management, following the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 and other relevant laws. Copies of the map and legal description will be available for public inspection. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT OF EXISTING LEASES. The Secretary is prohibited from allowing new drilling on valid mineral or geothermal leases within withdrawn lands to protect cave resources. Activities on existing leases may be suspended if necessary to prevent adverse impacts on significant cave resources. The Secretary is prohibited from allowing new drilling on valid mineral or geothermal leases within withdrawn lands to protect cave resources. The prohibition will remain in effect until a record of decision is made regarding the proposal to drill in the Dark Canyon Environmental Impact Statement, or for 12 months after the enactment of this Act. After this period, the Secretary is not required to permit or prohibit new drilling. During the specified period, the Secretary will negotiate with lease holders to terminate leases or impose restrictions to protect cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns. The Secretary will negotiate with lease holders to terminate leases or impose restrictions to protect cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. If no agreement is reached, the Secretary will take appropriate steps to address the issue. The Secretary will take steps to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park if no agreement is reached with lease holders. This may include acquiring the lands covered by the lease. The Secretary may acquire lands covered by the lease to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. Cooperation with the State of New Mexico and other landowners in the cave protection area is sought for managing acquired lands. The Secretary seeks cooperation from the State of New Mexico and other landowners in the cave protection area to implement restrictions on land use for the protection of Lechuguilla Cave and other resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. SEC. 6. ADDITIONAL PROTECTION AND RELATION TO OTHER LAWS. The Secretary will take additional steps to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park, including limiting access and prohibiting removal of resources for scientific purposes. The Secretary may limit access and prohibit removal of resources from lands owned by the United States to protect significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. If existing law is insufficient, the Secretary will inform the relevant committees for additional authority. If the Secretary determines it necessary to protect significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park, they will notify the relevant committees for additional authority. This Act does not affect the ability to seek compensation under existing laws or preclude any defenses or claims available to the United States.
